MEMBERS OF THE BOARD ROY L. COCHRAN — 1 .Governor HARRY R. SWANSON ! Secretary of Stale WM. H. PRICE ! State Auditor WALTER H. JENSEN — ' State Treasurer WM. H. SMITH . State Tax Commissioner LEGAL ADVISER TO THE BOARD RICHARD C. HUNTER Attorney General EDWIN VAIL 1. . Assistant '■'■•'. ■ ' I ■ ■ TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the Con - stitution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commis - sioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commissioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer ...April 25, 1921, to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923, to January 12, 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton January 12, 1925, to January 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT.Lancaster. January 8, 1929, to December 1, 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward January 8, 1931, to

LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA December 1, 1938. Honorable R. L. Cochran, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Governor: Herewith is submitted to you the annual report of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment and the State Tax Commissioner for the year 1938. In connection herewith I desire to direct attention to the val - uation of the state as returned by the county assessors and approved by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment for the four years of your administration, the valuations by years being as follows: 1935 $2,030,243,533 1936 2,060,835,168 1937 2,058,224,967 1938 2,033,302,482 It will be observed there has not been a very material variation in valuations during this period, although economic conditions have been decidedly adverse in Nebraska. In 1936 there was an increase of thirty million dollars, but nearly one-half of that was due to the passage of the act by the legislature in 1935, requiring that the assessment of motor vehicles should be made from the license rather than from a return made by the owner to the assessor. The total valuation of the state in 1921 was $3,312,737,091.00, and from that year until 1931 the variation in valuation was comparatively small, the total value for the latter year being $3,045,793,706.00. A very marked decrease set in in 1932, however, and valuations in 1938 were only about two-thirds af what they were in 1931. The present low valu - ation is attributed solely to the continued unfavorable crop conditions that have prevailed throughout the state. The general fund levy for 1938 was fixed at 2.68 mills on the dollar, as compared to a levy of 2.64 mills in 1937 and a levy of 1.76 mills in 1936. The levy of 1938, in connection with the state's share of the reve - nue from the intangible tax, imposes approximately the same amount of taxes that was levied in 1937. The low levy of 1936 was made possible

REPORT OF TAX COMMISSIONER only by the act of the legislature of 1935, which provided that the pro - ceeds of the liquor tax should go into the state general fund, and the estimated receipts in the sum of $1,138,007.87 were accordingly taken into account in fixing the 1936 j general fund levy, this having been re - ferred to in the report of this department to Your Excellency in 1937. In the latter year, however, the legislature transferred the proceeds of the liquor tax to the state assistance fund. This necessitated the general fund levy being increased in 1937 over what it was in 1936, and again in 1938. As a result of a study made by the State, 1 Auditor, of tax collec - tions in the various counties, it has been determined that approximately eight per cent more of the tax: revenue was delinquent on July 1, 1938 from the 1936 levy than was delinquent for a corresponding period end - ing July 1, 1932. This increased delinquency, following the transfer of the liquor tax to the state general fund, has resulted in an overdraft in the state general fund, but as a result of an act of the legislature, passed in 1915, the State Treasurer is ' authorized to carry such overdraft out of the balance on hand in other funds, and as a result, no state warrants have been registered. 1938 Assessed Valuation The following statement shows the assessed j valuation of the various classes of tangible property in 1938, and the percentage each class bears to the total: Item Valuation Per Cent 1. STATE OF NEBRASKA The foregoing total valuation is subject to the property tax levy in the sub-division of the state in which it is located. Intangible property is subject to a special tax rate, and the value of the two classes and the rate each bears is as follows: Class "A" - Money or its equivalent, taxed at two and one-half mills on the dollar $43,140,829.00 Class "B" - All other classes of intangible property, such as shares of stock, securities, notes, due bills, book accounts, claims and demands; bank, loan, trust, and investment com - panies, taxed at eight mills on the dollar $62,241,060.00 Meeting of County Assessors The county assessors met in annual session at Kearney on March 3-4, 1938, with a total of sixty counties represented. During the assess - ment period group meetings were also held at Omaha, Ord, North Platte, Sidney, Madison, and Tecumseh, good representations being present at these meetings. Ten bulletins were issued during the assess - ment period, subjects of importance to the assessors being discussed therein. Reports to Our Department The annual report of this department cannot be completed until the last returns are received from counties, these returns including the report showing the valuation and levies of the county and its various sub-divisions, and the footings of the tax list. Material for the first report is available as soon as the county board of equalization fixes the county and other local levies. The law requires the tax list to be completed and turned to the county treasurer by November 1st, when the personal tax becomes due, and the material for the footings of the tax list is available as soon as the list is completed. Nevertheless, some of these reports do not reach the department until the first of the fol - lowing January, and this delays the compilation of the material for our report, which should be available to your office and the legislature when it convenes the fore part olf January each alternate year. At the time I became Tax Commissioner, it was necessary for us to complete the collection of reports from counties after I came into office. This was because some counties had failed to file their reports before the change of administration, and not due to any neglect on the part of the former Tax Commissioner. I would therefore recommend some revision in the law so that our report may be available at an earlier date. Respectfully submitted, State Tax Commissioner

ROLLING STOCK ASSESSMENT The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is- divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the County Clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and then equalized by the State Board. STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT NO. 6 BASIS FOR THE 1938 STATE TAX LEVY The report of the State Auditor shows the appropriations from the state general fund for the biennial period of 1937-9 to be $12,373337.99 One-half of which was met from the 1937 levy, leaving to be raised in 1938, the sum of $ 6,186,919.00 The estimated revenue from the intangible tax is $100,963.00 Plus miscellaneous receipts as per auditor's report 804,843.38 905,806.38 Which leaves to be raised from the general fund levy $ 5,281,112.62 Which amount is increased 3 per cent in accordance with the provisions of Section 77-1007 of the Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929, $ 168,433.38 Making the total to be raised from the 1938 general fund levy $ 5,439,546.00 The valuation of the state has been found to be $2,033,302.482., applied to which a levy of 2.68 mills on the dollar will raise the sum of $ 5,449,250.65 Accordingly, the general fund levy for 1938 is hereby fixed at 2.68 mills by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment this 28th day of July, 1938.
